image.altText: Three women with colourful hijab under a cherry blossom tree

props.synopsis: One phone call sparked a community-led campaign to cover the relocation cost for a mother and her five daughters who had fled from Afghanistan to Iran on a tourist visa.

title.children: Community crowdfunding effort helps Afghan teacher to relocate to Australia

image.altText: A hand reaches for a glass of wine. A Harry Potter book is on the coffee table

props.synopsis: Australian wine exports have been hit by a global trend in people drinking less alcohol and cutting costs, but hope remains for the re-opening of a major market.

title.children: Bitter news for wine exporters as more people choose not to drink to save money — and health

image.altText: The embassy of the People's Republic of China was opened in 1990. Yarralumla, Canberra, 2017.

props.synopsis: A Chinese embassy official confronts Australia's new cyber ambassador after he told a gathering of diplomats in Canberra that Beijing was responsible for a series of devastating online attacks against this country.

title.children: Chinese embassy confronts Australian official who accused Beijing of cyber attacks

image.altText: A wanted posted in Japan

props.synopsis: It's relatively easy to disappear in Japan — so much so, there's even a name for the thousands of people who deliberately go missing each year: the Johatsu. The country's most wanted terrorist may have been one of them.

title.children: Japan's most-wanted man had a perfect cover to elude capture. But when he was drunk, he gave away a clue

image.altText: A police crime scene investigation van parked in a shopping centre car park

props.synopsis: An Adelaide court has heard that a father who stabbed his daughter in an open car park because she was dating a man of a different faith told his family "she deserved it", and the comment was recorded by police body worn camera.

title.children: Father who stabbed daughter in car park told family 'she deserved it', court hears

image.altText: Voluntary assisted dying recipient Lynne Wong.

props.synopsis: A year after voluntary assisted dying came into effect in South Australia, families of some of the 110 people who have opted to take that path describe their experiences.

title.children: Since SA introduced voluntary assisted dying laws, more than 100 people have opted for 'a death of their choosing'

image.altText: A smiling man in police uniform leans against a police car outside a police station

props.synopsis: The surviving family of Brevet Sergeant Jason Doig says it supports plans to erect a memorial to him in Lucindale, as SA Police looks to fill his role in the small country town.

title.children: Memorial for SA Police officer allegedly shot dead wins support from 'extremely proud' family

image.altText: A crowd of people raise their hands in the air at a gathering in Iran.

props.synopsis: Fears of regional escalation are growing as the Israel-Gaza war drags on, with data showing political violence has been at its highest in four main hotspots in the Middle East. All of those countries share a common ally — Iran.

title.children: How the Iran-backed Axis of Resistance is changing the stakes of the Israel-Gaza war

image.altText: Australians are due to receive a tax cut from July

props.synopsis: Which neighbourhoods, occupations and age groups are more likely to benefit or miss out from the redesign of the stage 3 tax cuts? We've delved into the data to find out how different parts of Australia compare.

title.children: The generations, suburbs and jobs most likely to win or lose from the revised tax cuts

image.altText: A split image, with F1 star Lewis Hamilton on one side, and the prancing horse logo of Ferrari on the other.

props.synopsis: Lewis Hamilton will complete arguably the most sensational team switch in Formula 1 history at the end of the season, leaving Mercedes to sign with Ferrari.

title.children: Lewis Hamilton signs with Ferrari for 2025 F1 season

image.altText: A saltwater crocodile leaping from the water eating a mullet fish at Cahills Crossing in the Northern Territory

props.synopsis: A dry season phenomenon draws both locals and tourists to the notorious Cahills Crossing in the Northern Territory. But a ranger says some people are ignoring warnings about the risk of crocodile attacks.

title.children: 'Someone's going to get grabbed': Kakadu ranger concerned about risky behaviour at notorious croc hotspot

image.altText: A graphic showing a group of school children and federal education minister Jason Clare

props.synopsis: There was a major development around funding for public schools this week. Let us break it down for you.

title.children: A battle is brewing over public school funding. Here's what's happening and what could come next

image.altText: A close up of Anthony Albanese in a suit and tie, wearing glasses

props.synopsis: Those wanting comprehensive tax reform aren't saying trust should be breached — they're arguing now's the time to put the tax system on the table for review, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Albanese has started a cat-and-mouse battle on tax — and a scare campaign will follow

image.altText: two men on stage, one playing a guitar and the other singing

props.synopsis: Aleksandr Uman's anti-war posturing drew the ire of the Kremlin, and now, he and his bandmates have found safety in Israel after an international saga that raised questions about Russia's influence abroad.

title.children: Aussie rocker avoids deportation to Russia, ends up in Israel after diplomatic stoush

image.altText: Workers at sewing machines

props.synopsis: Big clothing brands have been criticised over conditions in their suppliers' Myanmar factories, but now that some are pulling out of the country entirely, advocates warn workers will be left even worse off.

title.children: Workers turn to sex work as big clothing brands pull out of Myanmar

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

props.synopsis: Wall Street is rising again, with the Nasdaq benefiting ahead of results from major tech companies. While over in Europe, shares are sliding, after inflation data came out mixed and rates were kept on hold. Follow how the day unfolds on our live finance blog.

title.children: Wall Street rises ahead of Apple, Meta and Amazon results, with the ASX to follow

image.altText: Dyxi standing in front of a bedroom with a tarp covering a chunk of missing ceiling.

props.synopsis: As renters across the country continue to feel the pressure of an ongoing housing crisis, some Melbourne residents are finding their homes "unliveable".

title.children: A ceiling in Dyxi's sharehouse collapsed. She's stuck in Melbourne's rental market 'Hunger Games'

image.altText: An older woman with white hair sits on a couch. A temperature gauge in the foreground read 30 degrees Celsius.

props.synopsis: Sixty-eight-year-old Suellyn Lott's Sunshine Coast apartment complex was officially opened less than 12 months ago, but she says living there is unbearable when the temperature spikes.

title.children: Woman, 68, living in new social housing forced to take showers and hide in car to cool down during heatwave

image.altText: A close up of Donald Trump speaking in front of a large American flag and QR code

props.synopsis: A judge throws out a lawsuit by the former US president, who accused a British spy of making "shocking" claims about him.

title.children: Donald Trump lawsuit over allegations of 'perverted acts' in Russia dismissed by UK court

image.altText: An AI produced photo of a woman in a white dress with an older woman behind her

props.synopsis: The Brisbane Portrait Prize will allow AI artworks for the first time in this year's competition, in a move that has left some in the industry "uneasy".

title.children: Art world divided by prestigious portrait prize organiser's decision to allow AI entries

image.altText: An array of clear dropped bottles of different colours, on cream surface,  taken from above

props.synopsis: We look at the evidence behind some of the most common ingredients found in skincare products that claim to reduce the appearance of wrinkles and dark spots.

title.children: Skincare products promise to slow the effects of ageing, but how well do they really work?

image.altText: A black and white photo of spectators watching from behind a metal fence and barricades a car doing burnouts.

props.synopsis: Rival regulators compete to represent Australian motorsport.

title.children: 18-year-old spectator's death puts motorsport insurance under the spotlight

image.altText: Woman with brown hair sits in front of a car

props.synopsis: Planning experts say more investment is needed in public transport to support high density housing, as Greater Sydney's population is estimated to sit at 6 million by 2040.

title.children: Isabelle's commute became a 'hot mess' overnight. What solutions are there to Sydney's traffic woes?

image.altText: Zoe Arancini prepares to shoot

props.synopsis: A strong background of supportive legends has Australia's water polo teams ready to surprise the world at World Aquatics Championships.

title.children: How Australian water polo looks back to surge forward at World Aquatics Championships and on to Paris 2024

image.altText: Lara Alexander, John Tucker and Jeremy Rockliff.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian Premier Jeremy Rockliff issues an ultimatum to the two Liberal-turned-independent MPs who continue to threaten his government — get in line or face the prospect of an early election.

title.children: Tasmanian premier issues threat of early election to rogue MPs unless new agreement reached

image.altText: Premier Steven Miles sits across from ABC presenter Jessica van Vonderen in an interview

props.synopsis: Steven Miles is treading a fine line between acknowledging his legacy in the Palaszczuk government and trying to sell his "new" government, write Rachel Riga and Jessica van Vonderen.

title.children: There’s a political hot potato for Labor ahead of the Qld election – and it won’t be going away anytime soon

image.altText: Close up of Greta Thunberg smiling.

props.synopsis: A two-day trial begins after the Swedish environmentalist, who inspired a global youth climate movement, was arrested during a protest in October.

title.children: Greta Thunberg goes on trial for blocking oil and gas conference

image.altText: Blue fluorescent light-filled bakery

props.synopsis: In the heart of country Victoria, where banks are shutting their doors, many small retailers depend on cash — but it can be hard to come by.

title.children: Bank closures and empty ATMs leave regional shops relying on IOUs

image.altText: Jacinta Allan sitting across from Richard, engrossed in conversation.

props.synopsis: Since Jacinta Allan took Victoria's top job four months ago, she's put her own stamp on the office. But the state's 49th premier faces the same challenges as her high-profile predecessor Daniel Andrews.

title.children: We sat down with Victoria's premier and asked her your questions

image.altText: A woman puts a cashless debit card in a brown wallet

props.synopsis: They have pledged to bring back a version of the controversial scheme if they win the next federal election, suggesting there have been "devastating consequences" since it was scrapped.

title.children: Federal Liberals back cashless debit card reintroduction in response to crime, social issues

image.altText: Two men with their shirts off pose for a photo at a park

props.synopsis: The heat peaked before it even hit midday for many spots around metropolitan Perth, with scorching mid-40 degree temperatures experienced across the city.

title.children: Western Australia's severe summer heatwave breaks records as parts of Perth hit 45C

image.altText: Eva Lawler standing on a balcony overlooking Darwin City

props.synopsis: In an exclusive interview with Stateline NT,  NT Chief Minister Eva Lawler has vowed to press ahead with expanding the region's gas industry, claiming it will help speed up infrastructure upgrades across the territory. But she's also aware of a risk closer to home.

title.children: NT chief minister Eva Lawler on gas development, alcohol law reforms and the upcoming election

image.altText: Rainbow lorikeets in single beds in care.

props.synopsis: More than 200 birds with lorikeet paralysis syndrome have been taken in by wildlife carers around Grafton as researchers call on citizen scientists to help find the cause.

title.children: Rainbow lorikeets falling from the sky with mysterious syndrome in northern New South Wales
